results.title: Robin
results.creator_credit: Jan Sharp, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
Because she is overweight, Robin has had problems of acceptance with her peer group. The film explores the ways in which acceptance of group norms can affect relationships with people within and outside the group and the issue of peer group power structures at a school.

results.title: The Wind beneath their wings
results.creator_credit: Gwen Hancock, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a shy country girl, Gwen joined the Air Force when she was 18 years old and was posted at several locations around Victoria. Becoming a dressmaker after she was discharged from the army, Gwen married and lived life on a farm where she cultivated brown sheep, Shetland ponies and goats.

results.title: Kathy and Tracey
results.creator_credit: Graham Chase, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
An exploration of sex-role stereotyping of girls with reference to job opportunities, family support and expectations, and the concept of femininity. Kathy works in a bank and has just completed a modelling course. Tracey returned to school after modelling for several months. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Rui
results.creator_credit: Social Education Materials Project and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
Rui is a young adolescent with an industrial inner suburb as a playground. His family does not get away during the school vacation so in order to cope with his environment Rui and his friend Con act out fantasies borrowed from television police dramas. While offering positive criticism on improving the area he also displays how he has been hardened by his environment. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Craig and Steven
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
An exploration of the concept of masculinity. Craig is a ballet student and Steve is an Australian rules footballer. They discuss their views of life.

results.title: Susan
results.creator_credit: Jason Ollivier, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
Susan is the fifteen-year-old daughter of migrant parents and withwhom she is in conflict. She is trying to gain self-knowledge, and to sort out the problems she has with her parents, peer group and boyfriend.

results.title: Niki
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
Niki is a 14 year old schoolgirl who has achieved autonomy after the divorce of her parents. The film looks at the extent to which young people are capable of handling a large degree of independence.

results.title: Svadebka
results.creator_credit: Hans Hulsher, Nederlandse Omroep Stichting and RM Arts
results.brief_description: A studio recording of the renowned Netherlands Dance Theatre’s interpretation of Stravinsky’s Les Noces (Svadebka). Choreographed by Jiri Kylian, the piece pictures the ceremony of a traditonal Russian country wedding through a fusion of ballet with some contemporary influences. The dance engages with the rapid pace and intricate rhythms of Stravinsky’s score in a spirited evocation of the mystery of marriage, both its beauty and apprehension, particularly for the bride to be.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hans Hulsher, Nederlandse Omroep Stichting and RM Arts

The dance engages with the rapid pace and intricate rhythms of Stravinsky’s score in a spirited evocation of the mystery of marriage, both its beauty and apprehension, particularly for the bride to be.

results.title: Greg
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
An exploration of the lifestyle of a middle-class family in an affluent suburb and the family’s attitudes to success, competitiveness, and the raising of children. Greg attends an independent school whilst his younger brother, Richard, attends a government high school. An important theme in the film is the extent to which Greg is making, or is able to make, autonomous decisions about his own life.

results.title: Gary
results.creator_credit: David Haythornthwaite, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
After a period of abrasive conflict Gary’s parents have separated. The effect of this is shown on the whole family, but Gary is so deeply affected, that his insecurities produce a stomach ulcer. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Haythornthwaite, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
